headline: Skillet Corn Bread
description: This simple, slightly sweet corn bread is made in the versatile cast-iron skillet.
name: Skillet Corn Bread

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Place 9-inch cast-iron skillet in oven to warm it.
Mix milk and cornmeal together in small bowl and let soak for 10 minutes.
Sift flour, baking powder, and salt together in a mixing bowl. Beat cornmeal mixture, eggs, and butter into the flour mixture until you have a smooth batter, about 1 minute.
Remove skillet from oven. Swish vegetable oil in the skillet to coat; pour off excess.
Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, 18 to 23 minutes. Cut into wedges to serve.

review.reviewBody: I followed Penny Lundquist's directions, and used 1 t baking soda, 1 t baking powder, buttermilk instead of milk, added 1 T maple syrup and then cooked in a cast iron skillet with bacon grease instead of butter. Just having some now, and it's great! Not sweet at all, but a nice texture and flavor. May try doubling the maple syrup next time just to get a hint of sweetness.

Great recipe. I did add a handful of colby jack cheese and also used bacon grease in the pan prior to pouring the batter in. I also baked it for 28 minutes. My wife said this is the best corn bread I have made.

Exactly what I was looking for - an old school, unsweetened cornbread recipe! I also needed a no wheat flour recipe, so I took this and used almond flour instead. Only other mod was I used a Le Creusete ceramic coated iron round instead of a classic iron skillet - it fit in my toaster oven...
It's a good basic recipe. Easy to modify. We liked it.
I did mine in a muffin tin instead of a skillet and it worked great.

Absolutely the best corn bread ever! I modified as follows: used buttermilk, 1 t of baking soda, 1 t of baking powder, 1 T of maple syrup, I jalapeño very thinly sliced, I cup of finely shredded cheese (I used a mix of Colby, sharp cheddar, and Monterey Jack from Organic Valley), and I browned the butter in the cast iron skillet, eliminating the oil. This resulted in a cornbread cake that was high, light, and moist. I might increase the maple syrup by 1 T next time, but otherwise, this was perfect. I tested at 18 minutes, by 21 minutes it was done.
Love this. We add 1-2 cups grated cheese cheese and green chilies to this. It's a summer staple for us.
I like this recipe. I added a 1/2 cup more cornmeal and 1/2 less flour. Tastes way better now than the first time I made it.
was dry
a bit dry. added more butter and it was way batter
Skip right on past this recipe. It has no flavor/taste. Blah.

Nice recipe! I followed the directions and made only a few small changes: I substituted a generous tablespoon of bacon fat for extra flavor and reduced the butter by an equal amount, added two tablespoons of sugar and also diced up a jalapeno and a small red pepper to add to the mix.
It was delicious!
Made this but used Oat Milk instead of regular Milk and used salted Grass Fed Butter. Turned out pretty good! Nice and light. Good texture. Everything is better smothered in blackstrap molasses!
Tastless
It was SO bland. I even added sugar and jalapenos. As long as you cover it with butter and honey it will be fine though.
It comes out of the cast iron skillet with ease.
Loved it! I am glad that I read LIVE2EAT’s review. I followed the recommendations as stated in her review and I was rewarded with near perfect corn bread.
Came out great..I did add 2 tbls of sugar.
This is the first time I have made corn bread from scratch. Went by recipe to the T. It was spot on. My wife thought it was perfect (not crumbly or sweet).
Added 1/3 c sugar and 1/4 tsp vanilla extract.

This recipe was just right for us as there is no sugar and easy store cupboard ingredients. It baked perfectly in my skillet. I added diced bell peppers, mushrooms, jalapeños and grated cheese. Will definitely use again.

Love this recipe! I’ve always used Jiffy cornbread mix in the past, but decided to try homemade cornbread to go with chili. So glad I found this recipe! It’s the first one I’ve run across that said to soak the corn meal. It turned out fluffy and moist. Next time, I’m going to try adding a little sugar or honey to sweeten it up as other reviewers have mentioned. But my husband and I enjoyed it just as it was.
Turned out perfectly. Not too sweet.
It came out wonderfully! After looking at other reviews, I added 2 tbsp sugar, and I melted the butter as the pan preheated in the oven. I served it with a drizzle of honey on top.

My best skillet corn bread yet. My tweaks: 
- Add 1/4 cup of masa, 3/4 cup flour
- Add 1/4 cup chopped pickled jalapeños 
- Use bacon fat in place of oil for hot pan
- Tad bit more salt, kosher
- Sprinkle top with turbinado sugar before baking

Very good recipe! Our only change was that we added 1/3 cup white sugar to give it a little bit more sweetness. Texture was great - not too crumbly, not too cakey. I loved the crisp edge and nice browning the cast iron gave the bread. We'll use this one often. Thanks!

You have to add a few tablespoons of sugar to this and it’s great for a base to make with cheese or jalapeños! Rises great. I made a double batch and thought it seemed like slot of baking power.. but it’s great.

Easily the worst corn bread I have ever had. Corn bread is supposed to have flavor. I can't believe I wasted my good kerrygold butter on this. 

I actually did not know it was possible to make bland inedible corn bread. I'd also never made corn bread myself from scratch before. If I had known better I would have been more careful about choosing a recipe. Unless you like things that taste like baking soda and do not taste like corn or butter don't make this recipe.
Way, way too much baking powder. Taste comes through.
Delicious and easy. I added 2 tbs of pickled jalapenos. Yum!
It has been a _long_ time since I had cornbread this good!! I plan to add some corn and jalapeno peppers next time. Yummy. Thank you for posting this recipe!
This is such an easy recipe. I never bake, but this I make whenever i make chili. Just add honey to make it a touch sweet. Perfection!!
Great recipe. I modified with bacon grease and some sugar and it came out awesome

Five stars for simplicity, everything came out great. I did make some substitutions: grits for cornmeal and buttermilk for milk, as I had both of those and wanted to use them. The grits aren't great at first but they get tender over time, otherwise all was good... though I think I would prefer it sweetened up. I'm a bad person.
Easy and delicious. Not dry like some corn bread. Would make it again.
Delicious and easy. !!

This is a simple and easy dish to make so it’s my new default recipe for cornbread. I did a minor bit of tweaking including using part buttermilk and part milk. I also added a dash of ground chipotle pepper to give it a subtle zing. I’d probably be a bit more adventurous and generous with the chipotles next time. It disappeared quickly, so In our household, that signifies a winner.
I followed the directions down to the iron skillet but it was a little dry but still delicious. next time I'll add a little extra butter.

I followed the recipe for the most part - I omitted the kosher salt - and, it was bland. Nevertheless, I doubled the recipe and made enough for 2 8inch and 12inch skillets of cornbread. My guest loved it.

Delicious ??Made it last night.

 I added 1/4 to 1/3 of a cup of light brown sugar ( I prefer brown to white sugar). And prefer sweetcorn bread. 

This will be my go to recipe should another one come along (I'm doubtful thou).

Its that good. 

I also cooked it for 30 minutes at 400' the center slightly collapsed making it another wonderful part of this side dish!!!

I mixed 1 tsp. of honey and 3/4 stick unsalted butter and whipped it to a fluffy consistency.

Making another batch this morning last nights didn't last the night
Thank you!

I have made this a bunch of times as stated in the recipe and it turns out great every time!! My family loves this cornbread. It freezes well also. I have tried other recipes from this site, but my family says “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” so I go back to this one. So good!
I spread a layer of honey on the top while it was still warm. YUM!

My first time making skillet cornbread from scratch. This was a quick and easy recipe to follow. There were no modifications made to the recipe however I did spread a stick of butter across the top with five minutes remaining to cook to give the cornbread a golden brown top. I also cut the cornbread into four large triangles and immediately removed it from the skillet. Someone else had recommended removing it right away to keep the corn bread from crumbling and drying out. I made this corn bread to eat with red beans and rice, so the recipe was perfect for that however if I were to make again For another dish I probably will add sugar to sweeten it a bit.
Love this recipe! It’s my go to. I do use homemade coconut buttermilk, put 2 TBSP sugar because I like my cornbread just a hint sweet. I also use coconut oil in the skillet, but I follow

I liked this cornbread, but it was a little bit drier than I like. Loved cooking it in the cast iron skillet. The hot pan made a nice crispy bottom crust. I would make it again with perhaps a bit more liquid.
I added about four tablespoons of pure maple syrup and used a ceramic pie dish (because I don't have a cast iron skillet) and it turned out great!
Worst corn bread I ever made. Bitter, with a very noticeable taste of too much leavening agent. Massive disappointment
I used masa harina in place of cornmeal, and the texture was wonderful. Tortilla cake.
I had a little vinegar to the milk to make buttermilk and half a cup of brown sugar instead of regular sugar

I like this recipe. I will now use it whenever I make cast iron skillet cornbread. I see some reviewers suggested adding sugar, but it really depends how you want your cornbread to taste. I do not like sugar in my cornbread. I loved the natural flavor as it is. I used 2% milk and my skillet was in the oven from preheat right up to swishing the oil and adding the batter. It turned out well. Good recipe.
Great recipe. I followed instructions except added diced jalapeños and a little left over ricotta I had in the fridge. It turned out great.

I made a few alterations to the recipe: I added 1 tablespoon of buttermilk powder, and 3 tablespoons of sugar. I greased the pan with butter instead of oil, and brushed the top of the baked bread with honey butter.

I would make this again, but I would add more sugar (controversial, I know) and more salt. The top browned more than I was expecting, possibly due to sugar content, the positioning in my oven, or the additional butter. I'm not bothered by that, however. I just found it bland. 

Even if you prefer your cornbread to be savory rather than sweet, I would add about twice as much kosher salt, possibly more.
Perfect base recipe where your imagination can take wing.
I made the cornbread in a cast iron skillet. Perfect result as the bread simply slid out in one large golden delicious perfection.
Love this recipe. Have made
I made this recipe last night to go with chili con carne. It came out terrible, it was dry and dense and tasted really salty, no sweetness at all.
Very bland and salty. Wish we had added a 1/2 cup of sugar to balance it out. Next time!

I also added 2 T of sugar (I know, I'm a northerner), which I think was a good decision. I was very happy with it for being my first ever skillet cornbread. Perfectly cooked, but I think it could use more flavor. More salt? More cornmeal? I'm not sure.

So good and it was a breeze to make. I followed a few of the comment edits like placing the oil in the pan while it was preheating for a crisp bottom and adding a little bit of honey. Only reason I gave this four stars is because it is not sweet like the recipe says. I’ll definitely make this again and be sure to add a bit more honey because I like my cornbread on the sweeter side. Otherwise, great recipe!
Simple to make plain cornbread. Use bacon grease instead of oil. I used cornmeal mix and omitted the baking powder.

I wanted a loaf style cornbread I could slice and eat with coffee in the mornings. So I doubled the ingredients except for salt which I did 1.5x. Taste and eat just as nice as a regular loaf of bread. Very tasty and the texture is perfectly great. Loving it, thank you for the recipe.

Almost as good as our standard family recipe. I used buttermilk instead of whole and it was light and delicious!! Like my other Southern reviewer, I added about 1 1/2 Tbsp sugar to make it less “corny”. Will def make this again!
Love this recipe. Make it often.
Usually like sweet but family loved this one with their stew. No sugar at all.

I started my search for a cornbread recipe that didn't need buttermilk since I didn't have any, and don't love the substitution of milk + lemon juice. I agree with many reviewers who state that A) southern cornbread should not be sweet but also B) cornbread with zero sugar in it can be bland. So I followed the advice on another review and added 2 Tablespoons of sugar. I also cooked it in bacon grease because I had some from another recipe I had just made. This went together like a dream and baked up beautifully. Thanks for a great recipe!
Very easy to make and good taste and texture. I don't think cornbread should be sweet so don't understand why people mess up the recipe with sugar..
From the ‘Dirty’ South! I don’t always cook with, but I Definitely used bacon drippings instead of vegetable oil! I also added 1/3 cup whole kernel corn to add a ‘pop’ to the texture.
This was the best cornbread I've made. My family loved it. I added sugar.
I too am from the south & this is good I did add 1 c more of corn meal. It was yummy
I followed the recipe as is. It was bland and way too much baking soda

This was an okay corn bread. I like the idea of using the cast iron skillet. As written the cornbread is bland and not very sweet. I would definitely suggest adding 2 tablespoons of sugar or honey and instead of using oil in the cast iron I like to use butter. The butter creates a crispy on the edges of the corn bread.
My family liked it! It's Not sweet. I heated oil in the pan while preparing recipe so the cornbread had a perfect crust!
Like most reviewers, I add sugar. I do more than a 1/3 cup, less than a 1/2 cup. It's very good. Not crumbly at all like many corn breads. I don't have a skillet so I cook in a pyrex pie dish.

Perfect basic cornbread recipe that you can as a base recipe that is good as is, but if you like to "doctor up" recipes, this is the perfect base. 

If you want sweet corn bread just add sugar -- up to 1/4 cup. If you want buttermilk cornbread use buttermilk and substitute 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda for the baking powder. Add creamed corn if you want creamy corn cornbread. 

This is a GREAT base recipe to keep -- no need for 3 cornbread recipes. Just add want you want to this one.

Tips: You can melt the butter in the skillet, then pour it into the batter. No need for another pan. There'll be a little butter left in the pan, so you won't need the oil. Do NOT overmix. Mix all the dry ingredients together separately then use a large spoon or spatula to fold the wet and dry together.

This is a great recipe, I reduce the baking powder to 2 tsp. and add 1 1/4 C. Vanilla pudding (instant is fine), this makes it more dense and cake like but does not make it sweeter. Cooking time increases by about 15 minutes.

It was ok. Edible. I added a tablespoon of sugar and still found it really bland. It worked for the night to compliment my Chili but will look for a more flavorful recipe next time. 

What is nice about it, and why I made this version is that it has a very simple and common list of ingredients so I didn't need to run to the store. So from that perspective it's nice if you need it last minute. 

Next time though I will plan ahead and get a richer version made. 

Thanks.

I have made this recipe twice now. The first time, I added 2Tbs sugar for a touch of sweetness. The second time, I made it as is without sugar. I loved it both ways. The cornbread is tender, and I really like having a recipe on hand that uses regular milk for when I am out of buttermilk. I use a tablespoon of bacon grease in the cast iron skillet and heat that in the oven while I am prepping the batter.

I don't like writing critical reviews -- however I was not a huge fan of this recipe. Yes, I made one adaptation but that was only to add 4 tsp of sugar to the batter because I prefer sweeter cornbread. Other than that, I felt the cornbread came out a bit crumbly and "sticky." Overall, it was okay and I can't complain too much but it wasn't the best cornbread I've ever had.
This was great! Like my cornbread sweeter so I added 1/3 cup sugar. First time baking with a cast iron skillet and LOVED it. The pic says it all.

Yes, & it needed more sugar, & I added thin Pat's of butter when I 1st took the corn Bread out. The butter melted into the corn & there wasn't any additional butter needed. It rec'd great reviews from my entire family both sides.. 5- stars after I adjusted Sugar & butter also ck prior to 25 min., recommendation

I chose this after searching for a low-sugar recipe, because my usual recipe is super-sweet and I wanted to add green onion and shredded cheddar. It was surprisingly moist! My kids found this to be bland and dry but they are used to what I find to be an overly sweet recipe. I did add two tablespoons of sugar and my daughter thought the batter tasted "too floury," so I added two more tablespoons. I only added cheese and onion to half, and my son preferred the plain half. I also added a bit of cider vinegar to the milk out of habit (I never have buttermilk on hand). Don't be afraid to add the full 4 teaspoons of baking powder. I couldn't taste it (or maybe the vinegar neutralized any baking soda taste).
I quadrupled the recipe and made it in a 14" cast iron skillet. I also added 1/8 cup sugar/8 servings. The bread had a nice rise. I'll definitely make this again
I followed the recipe and my bread came out great and my wife and daughter loved it. Remember to use unsalted butter. Great recipe, thanks for sharing.

Didn't have a cast iron skillet (sigh), but I preheated a heavy stainless skillet in the oven and got a pretty good crust anyway. I used white cornmeal since it was on hand. I'd never seen the soaking technique for the cornmeal (and I'm a Southerner from a huge family of great cooks). I think this made the result exceedingly moist and tender. This is one of the richest-tasting cornbreads to ever cross my palate. Looking forward to tinkering with additional ingredients using this as a base. Might increase oven temp to 450 next time for a little darker side crust and top browning. This is my new go-to for cornbread.
Very good recipe. I doubled the recipe, and added one extra egg and a bit of sugar and then made fried corn pancakes. Yummy.

I have rarely eaten cornbread, but I knew hubby liked it so I've tried a couple recipes over the years. And I think this one is my personal favourite so far. I followed some other advice and added more sugar than what was called for (as well as garlic powder) and used bacon fat in the cast iron instead of oil. It gave the edges some nice crispiness. Overall, I loved it, and will use this one again.

This recipe makes wonderful corn bread. Just like you'd expect from cast iron. The only things I added was 1/2 cup sugar to the flour mixture, and fresh corn cut right off the cob from 1 ear of corn. Delicious. I've made it several times and it's always a winner!
The consistency is perfect. But this is bland and too dry for me.

My husband and I loved this! I think it was the butter and "fried" bottom crust that we liked the most. I didn't soak the cornmeal (forgot!), but prepared as usual... mixed dry together, added wet....I have an 8-inch pan and baked it for 18 minutes... It did fine.. I like that it is not sweet, but paired nicely with honey butter. I think next time I will try butter in the pan instead of oil... :-)
I added sugar as some of the other reviews suggested, definitely think it was needed. My husband and daughter loved it. Will make again.
I use this recipe and add a pint of my own frozen sweet corn. Baking time may vary, but it is absolutely scrumptious!
I added 2-3 tables spoons of diced pickled jalepeno peppers and 4 cloves of pressed garlic and a touch of sugar ..... on ofcoarse a cup of shredded cheese in the batter and 2/3 cup shredded on top...

Made this and followed the advice of a couple different reviewers. I placed the oil in the skillet while it heated up in the oven. I also added approximately 1/3 cup Turbinado sugar (what I had on hand). Otherwise followed the recipe as is. It has got to be some of the best cornbread we have had both at a restaurant and/or homemade.

I made changes based on the comments of others and I loved it. I used about 1 1/2 tsp salt, and added 1/4 cup brown sugar, green onions, frozen corn kernels and some cheese (didn't measure them). It turned out great. Good texture and it cooked so evenly in the cast iron skillet. I was really impressed with that and remembered that that is one of the features of cooking in a cast iron pan is the even heat. It made me think of trying other quick breads that way too. It also had a nice crusty bottom. I cooked for about 25 min. I would make it again with the changes I made to it as the basic batter is very good in terms of lightness and consistency.
Texture was great. Nice and moist. However, it tasted odd. Four teaspoons seems like too much baking powder. Will try again but with 1/2 or 1 teaspoon. Perhaps will try a little sugar, too.
Liked the texture and crumbliness. Not sweet AT ALL.
It was bland. I followed the recipe as is.
Some of the reviews said it had no sweetness so I added a tablespoon of sugar.... It was a huge disappointment . Even with the addition there was no flavor.
